lesson.name: Lesson 9.2 Teacher Guide: Completing the Square, Part 1

page.title: 9.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

Previously, students saw that a squared expression of the form \((x+n)^2\) is equivalent to \(x^2+2nx+n^2\). This means that, when written in standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) (where \(a\) is 1), \(b\) is equal to \(2n\) and \(c\) is equal to \(n^2\). Here, students begin to reason the other way around. They recognize that if \(ax^2+bx+c\) is a perfect square, then the value being squared to get \(c\) is half of \(b\), or \((\frac{b}{2})^2\). Students use this insight to build perfect squares, which they then use to solve quadratic equations.

Students learn that if we rearrange and rewrite the expression on one side of a quadratic equation to be a perfect square, that is, if we complete the square, we can find the solutions of the equation.

Rearranging parts of an equation strategically so that it can be solved requires students to make use of structure. Maintaining the equality of an equation while transforming it prompts students to attend to precision.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Comprehend that to "complete the square" is to determine the value of \(c\) that will make the expression \(x^2+bx+c\) a perfect square.
  • Describe (orally and in writing) how to complete the square.
  • Solve quadratic equations of the form \(x^2+bx+c=0\) by rearranging terms and completing the square.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Explain what it means to "complete the square" and describe how to do it.
  • Solve quadratic equations by completing the square and finding square roots.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 9.2.1: Different Forms of Perfect Squares
  • 9.2.2: Standard and Factored Forms of Perfect Squares
    • 9.2.2: Self Check
    • 9.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.2.3: Completing the Square
    • 9.2.3: Self Check
    • 9.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.2.4: Making a Perfect Square

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 9.2.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • None

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in "math talk" and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • factoring
  • factors
  • perfect square trinomial
  • quadratic equation
  • quadratic expression
  • perfect square trinomial
  • completing the square

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their intellectual humility.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Take Notice
  • Career Paths

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Intellectual Humility from Character Lab.

page.title: 9.2.1: Different Forms of Perfect Squares
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This activity reinforces the meaning of perfect squares and the fact that a perfect square can appear in different forms. To recognize a perfect square, students need to look for and make use of structure.

Launch

Encourage and support opportunities for peer interactions. Invite students to talk about their ideas with a partner before writing them down. 

Student Activity

  1. Select three expressions that are perfect squares. 
  • \((x+5)(5+x)\)
  • \((x+5)(x−5)\)
  • \((x−3)^2\)
  • \(x−3^2\)
  • \(x^2+8x+16\)
  • \(x^2+10x+20\)

Answer: \((x+5)(5+x)\), \((x−3)^2\), \(x^2+8x+16\)

  1. Explain how you know the expressions you selected are perfect squares.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: Because each of them is the product of an expression and itself. \(x^2+8x+16\) is equivalent to \((x+4)(x+4)\).

Activity Synthesis

  • Display the expressions for all to see. Invite students to share their responses and record them for all to see. For each expression that they consider a perfect square, ask them to explain how they know. For expressions that students believe aren't perfect squares, ask them to explain why not.
  • For the last expression, \(x^2+10x+20\), students may reason that it is not a perfect square because:
    • The constant term 20 is not a perfect square. (Most students are likely to reason this way.)
    • If 20 is seen as \((\sqrt{20})^2\), then the coefficient of the linear term would have to be \(2\sqrt{20}\), not 10.
    • Though students have been dealing mostly with rational numbers, the second line of reasoning is also valid and acceptable.
  • Invite students to offer other expressions that are perfect squares.

page.title: 9.2.2: Standard and Factored Forms of Perfect Squares
page.contents:
Activity (10 minutes)

In this activity, students begin to complete the square. They start by transforming given perfect squares from standard form to factored form, and vice versa. Then, they are given an incomplete expression in standard form that contains only the squared term and linear term. Students need to decide what constant term makes the expression a perfect square, and then write the equivalent expression in factored form. To accomplish these tasks, students must rely on the structure they noticed in an earlier lesson about the relationship between the standard and factored forms of perfect squares.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of two. Give students a few minutes of quiet think time and then ask them to discuss their responses with their partner. Follow with a whole-class discussion.

Student Activity

  1. What is the factored form of \(x^2+6x+9\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \((x+3)^2\)

  1. What is the factored form of \(x^2−10x+25\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \((x−5)^2\)

  1. What is the standard form of \((x−7)^2\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(x^2−14x+49\)

  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2−20x+ c\)?

Answer: 100

  1. If \(x^2−20x+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Answer: 10

  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2+16x+ c\)?

Answer: 64

  1. If \(x^2+16x+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Answer: 8

  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2+7x+ c\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(\frac{49}{4}\)

  1. If \(x^2+7x+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(\frac72\)

  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2+bx+ c\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \((\frac{b}{2})^2\)

  1. If \(x^2+bx+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: \(\frac{b}{2}\)


Notice that finding the value of \(c\) helped to create a perfect square trinomial. This is called completing the square.

Anticipated Misconceptions

If students have trouble determining the constant term in standard form, suggest that they draw a rectangular diagram and work backward to determine the factors along the two sides of the rectangle. Afterward, they can find the corresponding value of the constant term.

For example, for the expression \(x^2−20x+\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\) we would write:

\(x\)

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-10x\)

\(-10x\)

Which leads to the completed diagram:

\(x\)

-10

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-10x\)

-10

\(-10x\)

100

This diagram represents the expression \(x^2−20x+100\) (in standard form) and the expression \((x−10)^2\) (in factored form).

Activity Synthesis

Display the incomplete table for all to see. Ask students to complete the missing values or expressions.

Discuss how students knew what numbers or expressions to write in the last four pairs of expressions. Make sure students understand that:

  • If the constant term in the factored form is \(n\), the constant term in standard form is \(n^2\), a squared number.
  • The coefficient of the linear term in standard form is twice \(n\), or \(2n\).
  • This means that \(n\) is half of the coefficient of the linear term. If the linear term is \(20x\), the \(n\) is 10, and the constant term in standard form is \(10^2\)or 100.
  • If the linear term in standard form is \(bx\) (as in the last row of the table), then the constant term in standard form is \((\frac{b}{2})^2\), and the constant term in factored form is \(\frac{b}{2}\).

Explain to students that finding the constant term to add in order to create a perfect square is called "completing the square." In the next activity, we will look at completing the square as a strategy to solve quadratic equations.

9.2.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

Which value will create a perfect square trinomial when added to \(x^2-14x + \_\_\_\_\_\_\)?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

-7

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: After dividing the -14 by 2, square the -7. The answer is 49.

-49

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: When a negative is squared, it becomes positive. The answer is 49.

49

That's correct! Check yourself: Divide the -14 by 2 to get -7. When -7 is squared, it becomes 49.

196

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Divide the -14 by 2 before squaring it. The answer is 49.

9.2.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Completing the Square

When a number is added to a quadratic expression to make a perfect square trinomial, that is called completing the square. 

Here is how to complete the square of a quadratic expression, \(ax^2+bx+c\).

How to Complete a Square of \(x^2+bx\)

Step 1
Identify \(b\), the coefficient of \(x\).

Step 2
Find half of \(b\) and then square it. In other words, \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).

Step 3
Add the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) to \(x^2+bx\).

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial, writing it as a binomial squared.


Example

Complete the square to make a perfect square trinomial. Then write the result as a binomial squared.

\(x^2-26x\)

Step 1
Identify \(b\), the coefficient of \(x\).
The coefficient of \(x\) is -26.

Step 2
Find half of \(b\) and then square it. In other words, \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).
\((-\frac{26}{2})^2=(13)^2=169\)

Step 3
Add the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) to \(x^2+bx\).
\(x^2-26x+169\)

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial, writing it as a binomial squared.
\((x-13)^2\) 

Try It: Completing the Square

Complete the square to make a perfect square trinomial. Then, factor the trinomial.

\(x^2+8x+ \_\_\_\_\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to complete the square.

Step 1
Identify the coefficient of \(x\).
\(b=8\)

Step 2
Find \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).
\((\frac{8}{2})^2=4^2 =16\)

Step 3
Add the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) to the \(x^2+bx\).
\(x^2+8x+ 16\)

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial.
\((x+4)^2\)

page.title: 9.2.3: Completing the Square
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

Earlier, students recognized that an expression in standard form can be written as a perfect square and learned to write it that way. Here, they learn to use that skill to solve quadratic equations.

Launch

Consider keeping students in groups of two.

Display for all to see the two solution methods in the activity statement. Ask students if the quadratic expression in the original equation is a perfect square. Then, ask them to study the methods and make sense of the steps. Afterward, discuss with students:

  • "How are the two solution methods alike?" (They both involve making the expression on the left a perfect square. They are the steps for solving the same equation, so the solutions are the same.)
  • "How are they different?" (In the first solution, Diego first subtracted 9 from each side, and then added 25 to complete the square. In the second, Mai added 16 to 9 because that is what is needed to make 25.)

Tell students that either method works, but some people prefer the first approach because moving the original constant term to the other side of the equal sign (the right side, in this case) allows them to see what constant term is needed to make a perfect square on the left side. They also find it to be less prone to errors.

Student Activity

One technique for solving quadratic equations is called completing the square. Here are two examples of how Diego and Mai completed the square to solve the same equation.

Diego:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+10 x+9 &=0 \\ x^{2}+10 x &=-9 \\ x^{2}+10 x+25 &=-9+25 \\ x^{2}+10 x+25 &=16 \\ (x+5)^{2} &=16 \\ \sqrt{(x+5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{16} \\ x+5 &=\pm \;4 \\ \\ x+5=4 \text { or } x+5 &=-4 \\ x=-1 \text { and } x=-9 & \end{aligned}\)


Mai:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+10 x+9 &=0 \\ x^{2}+10 x+9+16 &=16 \\ x^{2}+10 x+25 &=16 \\ (x+5)^{2} &=16 \\ \sqrt{(x+5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{16} \\ (x+5) &=\pm \;4 \\ \\ x+5=4 \text { and } x+5=-4 \\ x=-1 \text { or } x=-9 \end{aligned} \)


Study the worked examples. Then, try solving these equations by completing the square for questions 1–5.

  1. \(x^2+6x+8=0\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+6 x+8 &=0 \\ x^{2}+6 x &=-8 \\ x^{2}+6 x+9 &=-8+9 \\ (x+3)^{2} &=1 \\ \sqrt{(x+3)^{2}} &=\sqrt{1} \\ x+3 &=\pm \;1 \\ x+3 &=1 \\ x+3 &=-1 \\ \\ x=-4 & \text { and } x=-2 \end{aligned}\)


  1. \(x^2+12x=13\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+12 x &=13 \\ x^{2}+12 x+36 &=13+36 \\ x^{2}+12 x+36 &=49 \\ (x+6)^{2} &=49 \\ \sqrt{(x+6)^{2}} &=\sqrt{49} \\ x+6 &=\pm \;7 \\ x+6 &=7 \\ x+6 &=-7 \\ \\ x=-13 & \text { and } x=1 \end{aligned}\)


  1. \(0=x^2−10x+21\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} 0=\;& x^{2}-10 x+21 \\ x^{2}-10 x+21 &=0 \\ x^{2}-10 x &=-21 \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 &=-21+25 \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 &=4 \\ (x-5)^{2} &=4 \\ \sqrt{(x-5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{4} \\ x-5 &=\pm \;2 \\ x-5 &=2 \\ x-5 &=-2 \\ \\ x=3 & \text { and } x=7 \end{aligned}\)


  1. \(x^2−2x+3=83\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}-2 x+3 &=83 \\ x^{2}-2 x &=83-3 \\ x^{2}-2 x &=80 \\ x^{2}-2 x+1 &=80+1 \\ x^{2}-2 x+1 &=81 \\ \sqrt{(x-1)^{2}} &=\sqrt{81} \\ x-1 &=\pm \;9 \\ x-1 &=9 \\ x-1 &=-9 \\ \\ x=-8 & \text { and } x=10 \end{aligned}\)


  1. \(x^2+40=14x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+40 &=14 x \\ x^{2}-14 x+40 &=0 \\ x^{2}-14 x &=-40 \\ x^{2}-14 x+49 &=-40+49 \\ x^{2}-14 x+49 &=9 \\ \sqrt{(x-7)^{2}} &=\sqrt{9} \\ x-7 &=\pm \;3 \\ x-7 &=3 \\ x-7 &=-3 \\ \\ x=4 & \text { and } x=10 \end{aligned}\)


Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

Here is a diagram made of a square and two congruent rectangles. Its total area is \(x^2+35x\) square units.

Diagram A

  1. What is the length of the unlabeled side of each of the two rectangles in Diagram A?

Answer: 17.5

  1. In Diagram B, we add lines to make the figure a square. The area of the square becomes a quadratic equation.

Calculate the equation, then put that equation in the standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) to answer questions a and b.

  1. Using the standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) to represent the area of the square in Diagram B, what is the value of the coefficient \(b\)?  

Answer: 35 

  1. Using the standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) to represent the area of the square in Diagram B, what is the value of the constant \(c\)?  

Answer: 306.25

  1. How is the process of finding the area of the entire figure like the process of building perfect squares for expressions like \(x^2+bx\)?

Answer: First, we had to figure out what number was half of 35 (which is 17.5) to find the side length of the rectangles. Then, we had to square the number 17.5 to find the area of the missing piece.

Video: Solve Equations by Completing the Square

Watch the following video to learn more about solving equations by completing the square.



Activity Synthesis

Select students to share their solutions to questions 1–5 and to display their reasoning for all to see. Encourage students to explain how they used the worked solutions to help solve the equations on their own. After each student presents, ask if others found the same solution but completed the square in a different way. Make sure students see that the steps could vary, but the solutions should be the same if equality between the two sides of the equal sign is maintained throughout the solving process.

Ask students how they could check their solutions. One way is by substituting the solutions back into the equation and seeing if the equation is true at those values of the variable. For example, to see if -4 and -2 are the right solutions to the equation \(x^2+6x+8=0\), we can evaluate \((-4)^2+6(-4)+8\) and \((-2)^2+6(-2)+8\) and see if each has a value of 0. Both \(16−24+8\) and \(4−12+8\) give 0, so the solutions are correct.

For students who need more scaffolding, print out the worked solutions and have students label the steps. They can then use these steps to help them solve questions 1–5. Students may also benefit from working so that each partner takes a turn doing one step in the process. 

9.2.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Find the solutions to \(x^2-10x=-9\) by completing the square.

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x=25\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\). The correct answer is \(x=1\), \(x=9\).

\(x=1\), \(x=9\)

That's correct! Check yourself: Add 25 to each side to create a perfect square trinomial. The equation becomes \((x-5)^2=16\). Taking the square root of each side, the equation becomes \(x-5= \pm \;4\). This results in two solutions. 

\(x=21\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: After adding -9 and 25, remember to take the square root of both sides. The correct answer is \(x=1\), \(x=9\).

\(x=9\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: There are two solutions. Remember to use the plus/minus sign when using the square root property. The correct answer is \(x=1\), \(x=9\).

9.2.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Solving Quadratic Equations by Completing the Square

Example

Solve \(x^2+8x=48\) by completing the square.

Step 1
Isolate the variable terms on one side and place the constant term on the other.
This equation has all the variables on the left.
\({\style{color:red}a}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}b}{\style{color:red}x}\;{\style{color:red}=}\;{\style{color:red}c}\)
\(x^2+8x=48\)

Step 2
Find (\(\frac{b}{2})^2\), the number to complete the square. Add to both sides of the equation.
Take half of 8 and square it.
\(4^2=16\)
Add 16 to BOTH sides of the equation.
\(x^2+8x+ \_\_\_\_ =48\)
\((\frac{b}{2})^2\)
\(x^2+8x\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}6} =48 \;{\style{color:red} + }\;{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}6}\)

Step 3
Factor the perfect square trinomial as a binomial square.
\(x^2+8x+16=(x+4)^2\)
Substitute the binomial square term for the trinomial.
\((x+4)^2=64\)

Step 4
Use the square root property.
\(\sqrt{(x+4)^2}=\sqrt{64}\)
\(x+4= \pm \;8\)

Step 5
Simplify the radical and then solve the two resulting equations.
\(x+4= \pm \;8\)
\(x+4=8\)          \(x+4=-8\)
\(x =4\)             \(x=-12\)

Step 6
Check the solutions.
Put each answer in the original equation to check.

Substitute \(x=4\).
\(x^2+8x=48\)
\(({\style{color:red}4})^2+8({\style{color:red}4}) ≟ 48\)
\(16+32 ≟ 48\)
\(48=48 ✔\)

Substitute \(x=-12\).
\(x^2+8x=48\)
\(({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}2})^2+8({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}2}) ≟ 48\)
\(144-96 ≟ 48\)
\(48=48 ✔\)

Try It: Solving Quadratic Equations by Completing the Square

Solve \(x^2+4x=5\) by completing the square.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to solve this quadratic using completing the square:

Step 1
Isolate the constants on one side of the equation.
\(x^2+4x=5\) 

Step 2
Find \((\frac{b}{2})^2\). Add this number to both sides of the equation.
\(b=4\), \((\frac{4}{2})^2=2^2=4\)
\(x^2+4x+4=5+4\)
\(x^2+4x+4=9\) 

Step 3
Factor the perfect square trinomial.
\((x+2)^2=9\)

Step 4
Use the square root property.
\(\sqrt{(x+2)^2}=9\)
\(x+2= \pm \;3\)

Step 5
Separate into two equations and solve.
\(x+2=-3\)          \(x+2=3\)
\(x =-5\)             \(x=1\)

Step 6
Check into the original equation.
\(x=-5\)
\((-5)^2+4(-5)=5\)
\(25+-20=5\)

\(x=1\)
\(1^2+4(1)=5\)
\(5=5\)

page.title: 9.2.4: Making a Perfect Square
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

For questions 1–3, what could be added to each expression to make it a perfect square?

  1. \(x^2+12x\)

Answer: 36
The constant term \(c=36\) can be added to make the perfect square \(x^2+12x+36\).

  1. \(x^2−6x+1\)

Answer: 8
8 can be added to the constant term \(c=1\) to make the perfect square \(x^2-6x+9\).

  1. \(x^2+14x−10\)

Answer: 59
59 can be added to the constant term \(c=-10\) to make the perfect square \(x^2+14x+49\).

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−16x=-60\) by completing the square. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:
\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}-16 x &=-60 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=-60+64 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=4 \\ (x-8)^{2} &=4 \\ \sqrt{(x-8)^{2}} &=\sqrt{4} \\ x-8 &=\pm 2 \\ x-8 &=2 \\ x-8 &=-2 \\ \\ x=6 & \text { or } x=10 \end{aligned}\)

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 9.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

  1. The standard form of an equation is \(ax^2+bx+c\). For each expression, find the missing constant \(c\) that would make the expression a perfect square.
  1. \(x^2−6x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Answer: 9

  1. \(x^2+2x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Answer: 1

  1. \(x^2+14x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Answer: 49

  1. \(x^2−4x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Answer: 4

  1. \(x^2+24x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Answer: 144

  1. For each expression, find the missing piece of information, including the sign, in the factored form \((x\_\_\_\_\_)^2\).
  1. If \(x^2−6x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to include the sign.

Answer: -3

  1. If \(x^2+2x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to include the sign.

Answer: +1

  1. If \(x^2+14x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to enter the sign.

Answer: +7

  1. If \(x^2−4x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to enter the sign.

Answer: -2

  1. If \(x^2+24x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to enter the sign.

Answer: +12

  1. Mai is solving the equation \(x^2+12x=13\). She writes:

\(x^2+12x=13\)
\((x+6)^2=49\)
\(x=1\) or \(x=-13\)

Jada looks at Mai's work and is confused. She doesn't see how Mai got her answer.

Complete Mai's missing steps by answering questions a–d to help Jada see how Mai solved the equation.

\(x^2+12x=13\)

Step 1
\(x^2+12x \;+\) question a \(=\;13\;+\) question a

Step 2
\((x+6)^2=49\)

Step 3
\(\sqrt{(x+6)^2}=\sqrt{49}\)

Step 4
\(x+6= \pm\) question b

Step 5
\(x+6=\) question b

Step 6
\(x\;+\;6=\) \(-\)question b

\(x=1\) or \(x=-13\)

  1. What is the missing term in Step 1?

Answer: 36

  1. What is the missing term in Steps 4, 5, and 6?

Answer: 7

  1. What is the value of \(x\) in Step 5?

Answer: 1

  1. What is the value of \(x\) in Step 6?

Answer: -13

  1. For each equation in questions a–f, choose the equivalent equation with a perfect square on one side.
  1. \(x^2+8x=2\)
    • \((x−7)^2=54\)
    • \((x+5)^2=12\)
    • \((x−10)^2=91\)
    • \((x+4)^2=18\)
    • \((x+1)^2=1\)
    • \((x+2)^2=9\)

Answer: \((x+4)^2=18\)

  1. \(x^2+10x=-13\)
    • \((x−7)^2=54\)
    • \((x+5)^2=12\)
    • \((x−10)^2=91\)
    • \((x+4)^2=18\)
    • \((x+1)^2=1\)
    • \((x+2)^2=9\)

Answer: \((x+5)^2=12\)

  1. \(x^2−14x=5\)
    • \((x−7)^2=54\)
    • \((x+5)^2=12\)
    • \((x−10)^2=91\)
    • \((x+4)^2=18\)
    • \((x+1)^2=1\)
    • \((x+2)^2=9\)

Answer: \((x−7)^2=54\)

  1. \(x^2+2x=0\)
    • \((x−7)^2=54\)
    • \((x+5)^2=12\)
    • \((x−10)^2=91\)
    • \((x+4)^2=18\)
    • \((x+1)^2=1\)
    • \((x+2)^2=9\)

Answer: \((x+1)^2=1\)

  1. \(x^2+4x−5=0\)
    • \((x−7)^2=54\)
    • \((x+5)^2=12\)
    • \((x−10)^2=91\)
    • \((x+4)^2=18\)
    • \((x+1)^2=1\)
    • \((x+2)^2=9\)

Answer: \((x+2)^2=9\)

  1. \(x^2−20x=-9\)
    • \((x−7)^2=54\)
    • \((x+5)^2=12\)
    • \((x−10)^2=91\)
    • \((x+4)^2=18\)
    • \((x+1)^2=1\)
    • \((x+2)^2=9\)

Answer: \((x−10)^2=91\)

  1. Solve each equation by completing the square, then choose the two roots.
  1. \(x^2−6x+5=12\)
    • \(x = -1\)
    • \( x = 5\)
    • \(x = 2\)
    • \(x = 7\)
    • \(x = 6\)

Answer: \(x =-1\), \(x = 7\)

  1. \(x^2−2x=8\)
    • \(x = 9\)
    • \(x = -2\)
    • \(x = 8\)
    • \(x = 3\)
    • \(x = 4\)

Answer: \(x= -2\), \(x = 4\)

  1. \(11=x^2+4x−1\)
    • \(x = 14\)
    • \(x = 110\)
    • \(x = -6\)
    • \(x = 2\)
    • \(x = 4\)

Answer: \(x = -6\), \(x = 2\)

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−18x+60=-21\) by completing the square.
    • \(x = -21\)
    • \(x = 9\)
    • \(x = 39\)
    • \(x = 78\)
    • \(x = -39\)

Answer: \(x = 9\)

page.title: 9.2.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
Reinforce the key points of this lesson by displaying some quadratic expressions such as:

  • \(x^2+4x+8\)
  • \(x^2+24x+144\)
  • \(x^2+6x+16\)
  • \(x^2−40x+400\)

Discuss questions such as:

  • "Which of these quadratic expressions are perfect squares? Which are not?" (The second and fourth expressions are perfect squares. The other two are not.)
  • "How can you tell?" (When in standard form, an expression with perfect squares has a constant term that is a number squared and a linear term that is twice that number. In \(x^2+24x+144\), we can see 144 is 12 squared, and 24 is twice 12. In \(x^2−40x+400\), the term 400 is -20 squared and -40 is twice -20.)
  • "Why isn't the third expression a perfect square? Isn't 16 a perfect square?" (16 is 4 squared or -4 squared, but for the expression to be a perfect square, the coefficient of the linear term should be 8 (twice 4) or -8 (twice 4).)
  • "Suppose we have two equations: \(x^2−10x+16=9\) and \(x^2−40x+400=9\). Which is easier to solve? Why?" (The second one, because the equation has a perfect square on each side. It can be rewritten as \((x−20)^2=9\). There are two numbers that can be squared to make 9, which are 3 and -3, so \(x−20=3\) or \(x−20=-3\).)
  • "Can't we simply rewrite the left side of \(x^2−10x+16=9\) in factored form and solve?" (Rewriting the left side gives \((x−8)(x−2)=9\), but now we are stuck. We can't use the zero product property because the expression does not equal 0.)
